Award.AbstractNarration:
This project pertains to an area of pure mathematics called symplectic geometry. Modern geometry is centered around the study of manifolds, smooth objects that at small enough scale look like the standard space of a fixed dimension; for instance, the surface of a ball is a two-dimensional manifold. Symplectic manifolds are equipped with extra structure that generalizes conservation laws from classical mechanics. Also, some models in string theory, a branch of physics, allow any symplectic manifold in lieu of space-time. This project studies the question: What are the transformations (that is, global symmetries) of a symplectic manifold? In particular, the investigator will use dualities predicted by string theory to further our understanding of these transformations.

This project aims to investigate symmetries of symplectic manifolds, using tools from Floer theory, singularity theory, and mirror symmetry. The most naive such symmetries are symplectomorphisms, i.e. diffeomorphisms which preserve the symplectic form. These form a topological group, the connected components of which give the symplectic mapping class group. This generalizes the "usual" mapping class group for Riemann surfaces. This project studies structural properties of symplectic mapping class groups, with a focus on four-dimensional examples coming from singularity theory. The investigator will also aim to understand the mirror phenomena in algebraic geometry. Symplectomorphisms induce automorphisms of the Fukaya category, an algebraic strengthening of Lagrangian Floer theory. The project will also consider "hidden" symmetries of symplectic manifolds: automorphisms of the Fukaya category that are not induced by symplectomorphisms, such as C*-actions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This is a project in symplectic geometry, a branch of pure mathematics that studies the phase spaces of mechanical systems. This field is centered around studying symplectic spaces, the spaces that are equipped with an extra structure that generalizes conservation laws from classical mechanics. The main goal of this project was studying the symmetries of symplectic spaces. In one direction, the PI (with Ivan Smith and Roger Casals) studied the diffeomorphisms that preserve the symplectic structure i.e. symplectomorphisms, of the 2n-dimensional disk with a non-standard symplectic structure (exotic 2n-symplectic disk). They show that for infinity many dimensions exotic disks admit a (compactly supported) symplectomorphism which, as a smooth map, is non-trivial. Moreover, the PI studied the properties of the group of symplectomorphisms for some 4-dimensional examples from singularity theory called Milnor fibers. In another direction, the PI investigated more ‘hidden’ symmetries. Specifically, it is natural to consider a class of half-dimensional subspaces in symplectic spaces called Lagrangians. Considering the geometry of these subspaces one would get a noncommutative space, called the Fukaya category. The PI investigated the automorphisms of the Fukaya category that are naturally interpreted via mirror symmetry. Mirror symmetry originated in physics as a duality between superconformal quantum field theories. Inspired by that Kontsevich conjectured "homological mirror symmetry”, that says many Fukaya categories are in fact equivalent to conventional commutative spaces such as those studied in algebraic geometry. The PI gives an exhaustive proof of homological mirror symmetry for hypersurface cusp singularities and simple elliptic singularities. 

 

One of the main tools used in this project is Floer homology, which is an invariant responsible for some of the most important recent advances in the study of symplectic spaces and low dimensional objects such as three-dimensional spaces and knotted closed loops in space (knots). In a different direction, the PI (with Eaman Eftekhary) used Floer homological invariants for knots, called knot Floer homology, to get numerical invariants that are lower bounds for the unknotting number and Gordian adjacency. These lower bounds can be arbitrarily larger than most of the formerly known lower bounds from knot Floer homology. The PI also investigated the formal similarities of knot Floer homology and Khovanov homology, a combinatorially defined knot invariant with roots in representation theory. In particular, introduced lower bounds for the unknotting number from Khovanov-type invariants and with Nathan Dowlin proved the knight move conjecture for knots with the unknotting number smaller than 3. Later it was shown that this conjecture does not hold for the knots with higher unknotting number. The main relationship between knot Floer homology and Khovanov homology is a conjectured rank inequality in the form of a spectral sequence, which was open until last year. The PI and Dowlin give a new local approach to prove this conjecture by defining a filtered braid invariant.  After closing up, this invariant computes Khovanov homology while forgetting the filtration it would be chain homotopic to Ozsvath-Szabo’s bimodule for open braids. Note that Ozsvath-Szabo’s bimodules are refinements of knot Floer homology for tangles. 

 

Finally, through the course of this grant, the PIs gave many research talks at seminars and conferences every year. Further, the PIs have given a mini-course at the 18th UK-Japan Winter School in Mathematics, aimed at graduate students and co-supervised a research project about Floer homology for the internal Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) program at Columbia University.
